commentBody: ‚Äúsbarro‚Äù two days in a row!
46 Across broke my brain for a bit, because my old brain saw ‚ÄúNorth Carolina SNL connection‚Äù and I was stuck on Robin Duke. ü§¶üèª‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è
There is a mistake in the 17 Across clue. The first word of the clue, rather than Classic, should be Former.
Three tries on my favorite clues -- I will try again later or tomorrow.
Nothing too remarkable today, but any puzzle which gives some attention to PETE Rose gets a thumbs up from me.

Peter Blair,
I find it ironic -- in the NYT Style-approved sense, of course --that copy-editing of the Wordplay columns is performed by the Flexible Editing desk.

This was a fine Monday construction -- thanks, Erica -- but I have an editing question. I know it's a Monday, but did we really need the bracketed additions to the three themer clues? The revealer (60A) sends us back to them to look at their starts; why give away the trick in advance?
Peter. we need you to re peat, three peat, again and again writing these columns.
17A is not a rose garden. It‚Äôs a monstrosity.
3:37 (on my phone), 17 seconds off my best, not quite a perfect solve, though, a few moments of hesitation. SEGUE escaped me, as did the spelling of ENNUI
This theme was completely lost on me. I was stumped by THREEPEAT and can only assume the starts of the three clues are names I should recognize. I didn‚Äôt. Not my favourite Monday puzzle.

I was familiar with the use of aubergines and peaches in the composition of a 67A, but TIL that tacos are employed. (Yes, I can infer the meaning.)

I suppose the limited availability of Mexican cuisine in my country of residence must‚Äôve played a role in my ignorance.
that was a very cute theme.
This puzzle gets a +1 from me for UBE.  My favorite purple ice cream.
Really too easy even for a Monday, except the theme, which I found impossible.  Then my streak was ruined by a flyspeck! (NYG)
I can‚Äôt recall seeing SBARRO, SERVER, or NEGLECT(S) in a puzzle particularly recently, but here they are twice in a row. (I mean, I didn‚Äôt look up when they last appeared. so I could be wrong.)

INS/NYG was a really awful crossing that needed attention by the editors. 

Otherwise a fine Monday puzzle.

I am new to doing the crossword and need to know when the new day starts.  It is 8pm Sunday and I just went to finish the Sunday game and now it is Monday.  This is when I finish for the day, I am busy otherwise.  I will never finish one at this rate

The very last message you will read about voting on THE GRIDDIES. Deadline is Sunday at 11:59pm EST for voting on THE GRIDDIES, the awards for the best NYT xword puzzles of 2025. We've recorded a lot of votes, but can always use more. The ballot is here: https://form.jotform.com/260176984868173 There are 4 categories, with 5 finalist puzzles in each category; vote for ONE in each category, hit submit and you're done! No personal information is required and anyone can vote.

Had to pause for a while to wonder what GOUP was. Until I realized it was a DOOK. 

Unfortunately,  references to the ROSE GARDEN just make me sad. Then angry.

For this member of the international contingent the theme didn‚Äôt click. The puzzle was definitely Monday level solvable without the hints so a clever puzzle either way. Thanks. 

Post facto I did realize I knew about Pete Rose and Pete Davidson. I can‚Äôt be bothered to look up 29A but will return here if someone cares to elucidate. 

SBARRO was a gift from yesterday where it only landed thanks to the crosses.
My speediest Monday yet recorded üôÇ
Would not have thought of Pete BEST as fodder for a Monday puzzle.

I suspect Mr. Blair brought up the irony definition controversy just to guarantee an extra busy comments section for his first Word Play.
Wouldn't it be ironic if turned out people were tired of the debate and skipped comments today? (Answer: yes.)

PS I really liked Pete's first Word Play.
Got 46A‚Äôs Pete purely from crosses. Does it count as a Natick if both direct clue and thematic confirmation are both relatively obscure?

My five favorite original clues from last week
(in order of appearance):

1. She's out there!  (7)(3)
2. Out of joint?  (4)
3. Means of closing up a vent  (3)(4)
4. Child support  (8)(7)
5. It'll never fly!  (3)


LES BIAN BAR  (altered to get by emus)
FREE
END RANT
SECURITY BLANKET
PIG
Delightful! And faster than usual. Loved the inclusion of some of Sunday's part answers too. Thanks!

My solving time today GOUPed slightly because of a typo. 

Happy brand new week, everyone.

Took a moment to remember the Pete from 29A, and was not that familiar with the one from 46A, either. Most of the puzzle was easily solvable, but I had one entry that was completely incorrect that had to be fixed.

Nice one Erica, and thanks!

I did this too late on Monday night to understand the revealer. My brain thought the first halves of the three theme answers were phonetic hints rather than the revealer. Ugh. At least I finished 4+ minutes off my average!
Call this one For Pete‚Äôs Sake? Where did that expression originate?
I knew all three petes, so I was pretty golden. Still way above my average Monday time because I‚Äôm using the clunky browser version.   Love these punny themes.
Vertex and Digits were my favourite NYT games back then :(

This takes me waaaaay back. When I was a kid, my parents had a ton of COMEDY ALBUMS that they would listen to every weekend with friends. I remember listening to Flip Wilson, Richard Pryor, Steve Martin, Bill Cosby, and Cheech & Chong. I was too young to know what they were talking about, but laughed when the adults laughed üòÜ I haven‚Äôt thought about this in ~50 years. I also remember when the Lakers tried to THREEPEAT in the 80‚Äô having grown up in Los Angeles and when they finally achieved it in 2002 under Phil Jackson who accomplished this impressive feat three times in his career as a coach!
Thank you, Erica, for this fantastic trip down memory lane.
I came here after I'd finished to see what on earth GOUPing was ... got it.  :P
This is the first time I can remember THE being an answer in all my years.
Hardly looks like a  rose garden anymore.

I had no idea what the theme was about ü§∑üèΩ‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è.

Except for the unknown GOUP, which looks like a letter salad, the fill was enjoyable enough, if somewhat trivia-heavy - mostly because it evoked some nice memories. And no, I don't mean those related to creative usage of üçÜ and üåÆ.

PECAN nuts were completely unknown and unavailable in Poland until very recently - I began seeing them at shops some 10 years ago or so. However, I had tasted them first much earlier. By the mid-1990s my English was almost as good as it is now, but I needed to practice it as much as possible with a native speaker. I can't recall how it came to be, but my mother learned about Joey, the Scottish wife of Tom, a manager from the UK working on some project in Warsaw at the time. Life in Poland then was extremely cheap then for people making Western money, so Joey didn't have to work, even though she herself was a well educated professional. The pair rented a luxurious condo at a duplex in Warsaw's fancy Mokot√≥w district, where Joey took care of her small kids, and offered native speaker English leessons. I loved our conversations - I can still remember her outrage at some of the Scots in "Braveheart" having Irish accents ü§£. Anyway... She once baked me pecan pie, to improve my cultural immersion. Wow! It was the best thing I had ever eeaten - I can still remember the taste, texture and smell 30 years later. So yeah, PECAN was a gimme.

MOW THE ROSE GARDEN?
SNOUTS CARESS CEOS (BLEEPED).
SCREAM! ERGO, ENNUI.

Found the overall puzzle very easy and finished in well under my Monday average with no googling, but had no idea what the theme was as I hadn‚Äôt heard of any of them - so had to google after the gold star to understand what I‚Äôd done!

I look forward to Monday crosswords as the one day of the week where I can get a trivia light simple fill that I can get through nice and quickly. This was anything but, especially for a non American. Not a great way to start the week üòí
I know, it‚Äôs a crossword clue, but ores are not metals and if you find metal in a mine, you don‚Äôt call it an ore.
I initially thought 60A was TRIATHLONS, and I must say the Pete theme eluded me... Otherwise enjoyed the puzzle!
This felt like the easiest Monday puzzle I‚Äôve ever solved, but it could also be that I‚Äôm finally getting better at this! Also RIP ROSE GARDEN.

I thought this might be a no-look-up no-reveal day but no, the Pete's got me. 

From last night's Burns Supper:

Then let us pray, that come it may,
(As come it will for a' that,)
That Sense and Worth, o'er all the earth,
Shall bear the gree, an a' that.   (take the prize)
For a' that, an a' that,
It's comin' yet for a' that,
That Man to Man, the world o'er
Shall brothers be for a' that.
Well, for Pete's sake, that was fun. Breezy, easy even though I didn't know the Petes.
I solved this one all on the crosses.  A small win, but much needed after a difficult weekend. Hopefully things will only GO UP from here!

I've a non-linear solving style and with a puzzle such as this I work in blocks of answers trying to remember as many clues as I can before filling in the answers. This all worked out pretty well 'ere I met [Increase] and just could not Gain a foothold. So thanks for the little grey cell challenge this morning. The 2 29A's that I can remember offhand were "Welcome To The LBJ Ranch" and "Bill Cosby Is a Very Funny Fellow . . . Right!" https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/%22Welcome_to_the_LBJ_Ranch!%22 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bill_Cosby_Is_a_Very_Funny_Fellow...Right!

Big shout out to Steph Curry, without whom I would never have heard of Davidson college and this probably would have taken a good bit longer. Also TIL it's in North Carolina.

As so often, I did not get the theme until I read the column, even though I know who Pete Rose and Pete Davidson are.
[[Writing implement] [jazz musician]] FOUNTAIN PEN Tiger Rag: https://youtu.be/a_qOmDVWu_g?si=-QEXaT6cst-fHrmV

A VENUE? Including an article seems an unusual route to take‚Ä¶ and I spent quite a while wondering if I‚Äôd gone down the wrong path with my Acrosses, checking every possible way. If this is now accepted in crosswords, I do worry about the general direction things are going!!
What‚Äôs a ube?
What Rose Garden?

I felt my IQ goup as I solved this one... unusual for a Monday.

GO UP, of course. A two-worder, where both words are two letters. I wonder if this is precedented? Barry A or one other the other regulars probably knows.

Clever idea for a theme, riffing off THREEPEATS.  Never been done before.  

Always sweet to run across words I like: DEMURS, SNOUTS, ENNUI, SEGUE, and CHERUB.  No to mention the lovely dook GOUP.

TIL: That THREEPEAT is a registered trademark by basketball coach Pat Riley.

Not intended I‚Äôm sure, but a lovely serendipity: Echoing the threepeat theme is a trio of three-letter palindromes (EVE, TUT, SIS).

This was an excellent intro to crossword themes for new solvers, many who come to Crosslandia never having learned that puzzles CAN have themes.

High quality and most enjoyable for me, Erica.  Thank you!

Who has time for "Tbsp." (or "tsp.")? It's "T." and "t." (periods optional), as in "Season with 1 T. lemon juice and 1/2 t. cumin," from my recipe for Fusion Baba Ganoush Fajitas, which I will gladly share with one and all, by phone message. Hi Peter! For the difference between coincidence and irony, Weird Al is here to educate you: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8Gv0H-vPoDc&list=RD8Gv0H-vPoDc&start_radio=1 (salient point at 2:42, with a very clever visual IYKYK--don't blink or you'll miss it!)
I had a lot of fun, solved it quite quickly as did my 10 mims walking on the treadmill. I did wish 2 answers hadn't been repeats from yesterday's puzzle (sbarro and neglect).

Did we really need to be reminded of grandeur lost with the first theme answer? I know it has already been commented on, but it still struck a raw nerve. 

Is there a category easier than a Monday puzzle? This was one of the easiest in memory. Though I never heard of Davidson College, and Pete was on SNL long after I stopped watching it, that was simple to get from the crosses.

And SBARRO two days in a row? SBARRO pizza isn't worth one day. Although I shouldn't talk, since I live in a pizza desert, along with bagels, and pastrami, and so much else to yearn for.

(third try)


THREEACT ‚Äì ‚ÄúHah!‚Äù, ‚ÄúWow!‚Äù, and ‚ÄúGood for me!‚Äù after cracking a terrific wordplay clue.  See also THREEJOICE.

THREEGRET ‚Äì Really rue a mistake you made in solving.

THREESPECT ‚Äì High esteem toward a particular constructor.

THREEVISE ‚Äì  Three times in a puzzle, throw in wrong answers, then eventually threemove them.

CC. ME.

Thumbs up.

Good Monday. Needed the crosses for a number of answers but that just made for an enjoyable workout. And had to stop and ponder once I worked out the reveal to catch on. No big deal. 

And - puzzle find today. This one was just a bit different. A Wednesday from April 25, 2012 by Peter Wentz. Seven asterisked clues in that one and the answers were: 

ACMILAN
RCCOLAS
DCCOMICS
WCFIELDS
ACCOUNT
JCPENNEY
MCHAMMER

And the 'reveal': 

SEVENCS

I'm done. 

....
I believe this way my fastest solve so far.

Odd that we‚Äôve never had a President named Peter, and only two major (sort of) candidates, Cooper and Camejo.

Maybe the most famous are Piper, Pumpkin Eater. and The Apostle.

I couldn‚Äôt figure out how to clue Townshend or Buttigieg.  On the latter, maybe the most famous last name from that island of stuff that dreams are made of.
Easy solve, although I can't remember anyone ever using the word DEMURS in real life.  And clueing RUE as "Wishes undone"?  Isn't RUE usually a verb?

Pete Rose‚Äôs brilliant career ensures that when we think of the Rose Garden today we will only think of excellence and honesty.

Found today‚Äôs puzzle too easy?
Here‚Äôs your hat-trick, what‚Äôs your hurry?

Fun puzzle, though I spent a while pondering what "goup" meant, and whether the ou sounded like "goop" or "gout." But anyway!  In the midst the tragedies of our time, is it wrong to cry for a lost rose? Not if we're still human.

Hmm...a new vegetable!?  I question if I could lay my hands on such a thing here, but it sounds delicious.  
A number of the clues/entries echo very recent puzzles.
At 37A I entered GAIN, and gradually had to change everythiing but the G.
Of course I knew PETE ROSE, but the others are Unknowns to me.  I last stayed up til midnight in 1989, so SNL was beyond the pale.  And any rock musicians?  Hah. PffT.
19 degrees here.  Will wait and see what survives in the flower bed...

Wow. I might technically be COSPLAYing right now, in my pajamas that look like a Starfleet uniform, but I did not get that until the very end, on crosses, and still failed to parse it. (My brain: "What's c≈çs play?")

The problem is, I've been going to fan conventions for decades, and have seen cosplay at all of them, so "modern" had me thinking video games. 

Whether any of this is ironic is left as an exercise to the reader.

One more puzzle find. A Sunday from March 2, 2003 by Brendan Emmett Quigley with the title: "Stop me if you've heard this one." Theme answers: WHYDIDTHECHICKENCROSS WHATDOYOUCALLABLONDE APRIESTARABBIANDAMONK HOWMANYLAWYERSDOESIT THREEGUYSWALKINTOABAR Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=3/2/2003&g=104&d=A ...
A rare "no look-ups" puzzle for me.  Fifteen minutes, pretty smooth flow.
GOUP?

Oohhh - and one more puzzle find. One of the most amazing I've ever seen. A Sunday from February 9, 1975 by William Lutwiniak with the title "Companions." Five 23 letter grid-spanning theme answers. Those answers and their clues: "Bears" GRIZZLYKODIAKANDCHICAGO "Eagles" PHILADELPHIAANDAMERICAN "Cards" STLOUISPOSTALANDPLAYING "Saints" NEWORLEANSJAMESANDPETER "Patriots" NEWENGLANDANDPAULREVERE Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=2/9/1975&g=114&d=A ....

Ok this was a groaner theme‚Ä¶ yet again‚Ä¶ but it does it bother anyone else that the revealer is plural when it shouldn‚Äôt be? If we have three Petes in the entries then we only have ONE three-peat. Not threepeats. 

Or I‚Äôm just grumpy bc it‚Äôs so‚Ä¶ icy outside.
Felt like a Tuesday.

Any puzzle that begins with a slice of PECAN pie is fine by me. My mother bakes one for me every Thanksgiving, because I can't stand pumpkin pie. (I think it's the allspice that gets me.

On the downside, I can't see SBARRO without thinking of the terror attack in Jerusalem, and that was 25 years ago. I certainly don't think of quality pizza, but they're definitely a food court fixture.

Well the sun is shining, I've had my coffee, so it's time to shovel some snow. HOA crew did a lackluster job of plowing the streets, though, so there might be some swearing.
Thoroughly enjoyed todays crossword and my fastest solve!
breezed through this, very enjoyable
Ah, I should have had DAVIDSON COLLEGE right away. It's less than a mile from my house! But we have a bit of an inferiority complex here and I thought "No way that's making the NYT crossword puzzle"!

My idiot moment of the day: "Goup? That's not a word... I think... maybe it's cool new slang."

Got stuck on that for sooooo long.

THREEACT ‚Äì ‚ÄúHah!‚Äù, ‚ÄúWow!‚Äù, and ‚ÄúGood for me!‚Äù after cracking a terrific wordplay clue.  See also THREEJOICE.

THREEVISE ‚Äì A trio of times in a puzzle, throw in wrong answers, then eventually threemove them.
I think the ‚Äú60s musician‚Äù is way too vague.  Should have been something like ‚ÄúFifth Beatle‚Äù or ‚ÄúReplaced Ringo‚Äù or ‚ÄúAn original Fab Four‚Äù
‚ÄúGoup‚Äù is increase? Help me understand this please üôèüèæ
Rose Garden clue maybe should reflect past tense aspect.

FYI: I once had an ESL student from Guadalajara, Mexico, which is nicknamed "The City of Roses." We visited a rose garden in California. She grabbed s small branch from a rose bush and stuck it in the ground. She said a new rose bush would grow. I've tried it over and over and it works!! Let a thousand rose gardens bloom. I also watched a video the other day which taught me how to grow a rose plant in a potato: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IWFPSrFQZ_Y
When will I figure out a 4 letter brother or son in the Bible is ESAU! Such great letters he had.  ü§£
First time under 10:00!!!! (9:01)

Thanks for the Weird Al link. I've been running into an engaging solecism today: Sam Darnold has finally overcome his (perceived) tendency to perform poorly in big games, and therefore has exercised his demons. I picture him ("his," actually) walking his two very badly behaved dogs.
Pretty sloppy puzzle as evidenced by the comments. And that Southwest corner! Brutal for a Monday.
Absolutely brilliant. Solved it under 45 minutes thanks to my girlfriend. She is 2 years older than me, so she's way smarter for at least six months, after which she becomes 1 year smarter.
Speaking of irony, I love Alanis Morissette, but her examples of things Ironic are not irony, just bad luck.
Tell me more about this so-called "Rose Garden".
My 77 Sunset Strip brain really struggled with this Monday. ;)
As a DAVIDSON COLLEGE alumnus, what a pleasant surprise to see my alma mater appear. Thoroughly enjoyed this puzzle!

Very late, but reading through the comments, and feeling that I am not alone in my "rose garden" thoughts, nor my general sense of horror and despair. I deeply hope that the Minnesotans among us feel supported. 
Also hope that all reading this who were affected by the weekend storm are safe, and at least have their power back. Here in CT, I shoveled 18", and am keeping my coal stove running through this cold week. (Secondary heat source, but welcome when needed.)
Stay warm, friends!

One more answer history search was inspired by multiple comments about ROSEGARDEN. I went and looked for: 

IBEGYOURPARDON 

That was an answer in only one puzzle - a Monday from August 6, 2001 by Bernice Gordon. 

I can't help but wonder how many of you will get that connection. 

...

What a fun puzzle! I will confess that I do cook and bake but did not know the Ube yam. Always good to learn a new three letter word. I also really enjoyed our guest columnist today and hope to hear from him again.
Eggplant and Taco emoji's ??? NYT you are making me blush
üåÆ turned on yet?
I miss Vertex so much!! I loved that game.

Four Pete‚Äôs sake:

[1999 found footage horror film [head of NYT Flexible Editing desk]]?

BLAIRWITCHPROJECT
not me trying to figure out what BEST COME DYAL BUM is‚Ä¶‚Ä¶‚Ä¶‚Ä¶‚Ä¶. Trickier than a usual Monday but I think I just wasn‚Äôt clicking with it :‚Äô)
GOUP threw me. I couldn‚Äôt find it in a dictionary. Finally read WordPlay to discover it was GO UP. üôÑ

@pmom

Are you suggesting today's answer waSBARROwed from yesterday's puzzle?

@Barry Ancona
Sigh!

@Barry Ancona

Yes, obviously someone's not keeping up with the "alterations" being made at 1600 Pennsylvania Ave.
@Barry Ancona It's still called the Rose Garden, regardless of how much grass is there. An event held on the patio would still be scheduled at "The Rose Garden." See also: Madison Square Garden

Steven M.,
Please read my post again. I'm not objecting to the answer. The error is in the clue.

Steven M.,
P.S. You do know that even the first Madison Square Garden was not a garden? Unlike its successors, it was adjacent to Madison Square.
@Steven M. But it will no longer flower, so the clue isn't right

@Leontion
It's OK, Pete ROSE is arguably not a ballplayer. So it all evens out.

@Francis Look at the third picture, it's pretty clear. It's also the same place the majority of the flowers were before the renovation. It's not like the grass the was paved had a bunch of flowers, just a small area of roses. It was predominantly a seating area that got paved over, so obviously it was not heavily flowered. The clue remains accurate

@Steven M.

Ok, if you say so.

The third picture looks to me to be a bunch of PVC 
piping, with even fewer flowers present.

Maybe you're pulling a great trick here, or maybe I just too many steps behind.

@SBK

OH SNAP...

@Francis not sure if you're being deliberately obtuse or what, but third picture, far right of the frame, it's exactly the same area of flowers that existed before Trump paved over the grass. The area that got paved over, never grew flowers

@Steven M.

It's hard for even me to tell sometimes if I'm being deliberately obtuse, so don't feel bad.

I really honestly don't know how to resolve this.  I went back to the link you provided.  Maybe it's presenting to me in some way different on my device, but I just don't see what you are seeing, apparently.

I mean no disrespect.  So, no hard feelings, I hope.

@Barry Ancona

Yes, it should renamed the Donald Trump Paved Patio. Ugh.

@Barry Ancona

I knew if I opened the comments section that this would be here.

@Barry Ancona 
First thing that, sadly, came to mind. ü•Äüòû

@Barry Ancona

That should be the worst of our worries. The grounds crew from Nationals Park could revert that area to lawn in a matter of hours. Correcting other things will take generations.

Steve,
1. No kidding.
2. The "other things" weren't in the crossword, and I was commenting on the crossword.

@Steve L
But that is the purpose of emblems -- to distill and remind us of larger and more abstract things. The ruins of your country's government can't easily be visualised but a picture of Trump's Tacky Terrace is a clear instance of the replacement of loveliness with cheap tawdry crushing ugliness.

@Lewis

No threepeat for you!
P.S. A copy editor should have edited your bio; I trust the Flexible Editing desk copy-edits quite a bit more than just the Wordplay columns.

@NYC Traveler
I suspect it's like every flex-position. Every few days or so you're shoved into a new cubicle, handed a pile of material, and told, 'Here, handle this.' Little or no training or instruction, no supervision, and best of luck to ya! Great if you have a short attention span and thrive on stress.

The Flexible Editing desk does a reasonably good job of seeing that the Wordplay column conforms to reasonable language and NYT Style, but if they are supposed to be copy editing, they should be fired. There are always errors in the columns -- from "typos" on up -- as should be expected from any good writers whose work is not copy-edited. Copy editing includes checking for accuracy. The staff on the Flexible Editing desk should be called stylists; they are not copy-editing. Copy editing (also known as copyediting and manuscript editing) is the process of revising written material ("copy") to improve quality and readability, ensuring that a text is free of errors in grammar and style and that it is accurate. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Copy_editing

@Barry Ancona

Need any help with that soapbox? üòã

Joan,
Cleverness has nothing to do with it.
Did you read all of the 60A clue?

@Barry Ancona
No, I didn't....  I was in a bit of a rush to solve!  The puzzle is even more nice, now that I know of the three Petes.

Joan,
You've told us you've been doing crosswords since before there were timers. May I suggest you slow down a bit and try to read all of the clues, in full? And glance at the crosses? You may find you will need fewer cheats! 
Happy solving!
@Steven M. Amazing! I couldn't enter the answers on the phone that fast even if I had them perfectly memorized.
@Bob I once did the following experiment. Solve a puzzle. Clear the grid. Solve it again to see how fast I could fill it knowing all the answers. It was just over 2 minutes

Petrol,
You might know Pete BEST, a.k.a the 5th Beatle. You get a pass -- if not a visa -- for not knowing Pete the baseball star or Pete the former SNL cast member.

@Petrol - They are two American cultural references and  Brit cultural reference.  Pete Rose was a baseball player disgraced for betting on his own team.  Pete Davidson is a current comedy star.  Pete Best was the drummer for the Beatles before Ringo Starr.

@jennie

PETE Rose wasn‚Äôt just a baseball player. He‚Äôs the player who set a record for the most hits, a record that has remained since the 80s. Who then disgraced himself as you said, and for that reason, is not in the Hall of Fame. He would have been a shoo-in otherwise.

@Steve L emus keep eating my posts.... Pete Rose, Charlie Hustle, did great damage to Ray Fosse by colliding with him at home plate rather than sliding. In a meaningless All-Star game. That, I cannot abide. https://tinyurl.com/mwr8zs37

@Steve L I know I'll be stepping on toes here, but I'll never forgive him for what he did to Ray Fosse in a stupid All-Star game: https://tinyurl.com/mwr8zs37 I realize hustle is a part of the game, but this looked like targeting to me.

@Francis

I'm with you on this.  In an All-Star game!?

@Barry Ancona Seriously??? I am a huge Beatles fan so I know Pete Best, of course, but I‚Äôd be surprised if he is even In the top 500 when it comes to 1960s rock musicians. This was not Monday-level easiness! 

Pete Best is to 1960s rock music as Lady Jane Grey is to the British Monarchy: doesn‚Äôt immediately spring to mind!

@Al  in Pittsburgh

I actually remember watching this game live.  I wanted the National League to win, but the horrendous collision that Rose insisted on immediately made me sick for ever rooting for his team.

@Petrol

The theme was as ungettable for a non-USonian as it gets.

@Francis.   I have mixed feelings.   2 things:  At that time - before huge salaries made the All Star game more of a show than a game - the players played a real game, not a show game.  And second, a lot of people who played baseball have said that it's part of the game.    Plate collisions were not uncommon.  If a catcher is protecting the plate, as Fosse was, the runner can bowl him over in order to reach the plate.  They have more recently (2014) changed the rule - catchers can't block the plate.

@Dave

True, it was more part of the game then than now.  And the All-star game was more contentious than it is now, for whatever reason.

Still, it was certainly a topic of controversy at the time, so the exhibition nature of the all-star game was recognized.

And Rose never apologized to Fosse.  If I did something that caused a person life-long pain, even completely accidentally, I'd apologize.  Or at least express some regret that it had happened.

@Francis
I think the ASG was devalued as soon as interleague play during the season was allowed. (Forgot the year.)  Until then, the only way you could see that great batter from the other league get mowed down by your team's lefty ace was if both teams reached the World Series.  More to the point, it was the only chance for the players to test themselves against the other league's best.
Always an unlikely event, /pace/ Yankee fans' arrogance and egos.
Now it might happen any Monday evening in July. So, the ASG seems less thrilling.

The only time in my life have I been somewhere with so much national and international attention was at the Boston Marathon on the day it was bombed.  The only time I didn't complete a marathon I started (it was closed with me about ten minutes from finishing).

After hours trying to get in touch with my wife, we finally got back to the hotel room, and I was just stunned by the coverage.  The aerial view of the finish line that I had been a couple hundred yards from, but never saw, was ghastly.

@Andrzej I am quite surprised you liked it - awfully sweet for European tastes I would have thought.  I also love pecans and always bring two large bags back when I visit the States.

@Andrzej
My big question is, how were you taught to pronounce PECAN?
(Southern cooks have strong feelings about this.  Many states--especially Louisiana and Texas--have pecan ranches. We all consider ourselves experts.)
The worst example of mistaken pronunciation is PEE-can.
Enlightened folk say, "pih-CAHN."
This Christmas I used Agave syrup instead of Karo (corn)  syrup...no harm done, and a healthier pie, so... it's never too late to change, eh?
I also add chopped pecans to tuna salad,  It is the preferred nut for cinnamon buns/schnecken.

@Mean Old Lady

Honestly? I can't remember how Joey pronounced it. I have a tendency to say it PEE-can, so sadly I'd upset you if you heard me.

BTW. If I'm remembering this correctly, Joey asked if I had ever had pecan pie. I didn't really understand. What's a pecan, I asked. She went on to explain it's a nut, and I was very surprised - I knew walnuts and hazelnuts, as by then they had been grown and eaten in Poland for centuries. We also imported peanuts. But... There actually exist *more* types of nuts?! Wow!

These days you can buy all sorts of nuts (in the broadest sense) in Poland, including ones not available before - pine nuts, pecans, Brazil nuts, cashews, Macadamia nuts, etc. How the world has changed - at least partly for the better!

@Mean Old Lady
Healthier pecan pie? Pretty sure that's an oxymoron. Karo is regular corn syrup (glucose), not high-fructose corn syrup, which I agree is best avoided. Agave syrup is almost all fructose, which isn't very good for you. Some sources say it's a lot worse than even high-fructose corn syrup. And that's got to mess with the texture of your pie. 

But both syrups are simply empty calories. The nuts are protein and fiber, so that's good! 

I'd still happily eat a pecan pie, just not the whole thing. Plus some whipped cream, I hope.

@Andrzej

Love your story about Joey! What wonderful memories! 

It's not my most favorite, but I do enjoy a good pecan pie. Last summer, my boss had his annual summer party at his house on one of Minnesota's 10,000+ lakes and we all bring food to share. I had gotten a weird hankering for pecan pie, so I decided to get one from a nice local bakery to share, although I do bake a mean one. This way, I could have a piece and do away with the hankering, but not have to eat it all myself. (My husband isn't a fan of nuts in things. He's a nut purist.) 

Anyhow, turned out no one else at the party likes pecan pie. I was the only one who ate any and my boss handed it back to me at the end. ü§Ø

So guess who had to eat the whole pie herself?! I mean, it wasn't the worst thing that ever happened to me...  üòã Fortunately, it stays good in the freezer, so I froze it in pieces, so I didn't have to have it every day. It was an oddly happy, high-caloric problem to have. Yum!

@John

Andrzej is spot on.

Crosswords are fuzzy logic.  There isn't a formal proof path from the clue to the answer.  That would probably be impossible, but would certainly be as boring as most Superbowls.

Fuzzy logic is how we operate.  Our brains don't wait for absolute proof--they go off what they think gives us the best chance to survive.  

We do it every day, all day, and it only seems weird when it comes in the form of a crossword puzzle.

Here in the US routine medical exams now include what I call the "Medicare Memory Test" where the nurse will give you 4 unrelated words at the beginning and then ask you to recall them later. @Sam
Probably not in London. In the UK, the word is used (rarely) for rural or suburban streets in residential areas, specifically tree-lined ones. There are avenues in the UK, but never (as far as I know) a part of an urban street grid system, as is done in New York and other American cities.
Let's go here: https://www.caffeconcerto.co.uk/locations/united-kingdom/central-london/caffe-concerto-shaftesbury-avenue

@Lavinia
In cities such as Seattle (I recently noticed), AVENUEs go North/South, and Streets go East/West.

Re the Rose Garden, from Wikipedia:
"The White House Rose Garden was established in 1913 by Ellen Louise Axson Wilson, wife of Woodrow Wilson, and designed by landscape architect George Burnap.[3][4] In 1935, President Franklin D. Roosevelt commissioned Frederick Law Olmsted Jr. to redesign the garden, and he installed cast iron furniture pieces.[5]"

Olmstead was also the architect of Central Park. 

The Rose Garden was then updated during the Kennedy administration.
AND THEN:
"First Lady Melania Trump commissioned an August 2020 renovation of the garden by Oehme, van Sweden and Perry Guillot. In the flower beds, white and pale pink rose bushes are intermixed with seasonal bulbs and annuals, including the Pope John Paul II Rose in honor of the first time a pope visited the White House in 1979. A new limestone walk, 36 inches (91 cm) wide to comply with the Americans with Disabilities Act, was laid around the borders of the garden."
